cards.back: A tool for building, changing, and versioning infrastructure efficiently using infrastructure as code.
Plugins that Terraform uses to interact with cloud providers, SaaS providers, and other APIs.
A set of practices that leverages Git workflows to manage infrastructure and application configurations.
A lightweight, standalone, executable package that includes everything needed to run a piece of software, including the code, runtime, system tools, libraries, and settings.
A platform that enables developers to build and package applications into containers, ensuring they work seamlessly in any environment.
An open-source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.
The smallest deployable units created and managed by Kubernetes, usually containing one or more containers that are deployed together.
The process of automatically adjusting the number of computing resources to meet demand.
Increasing the number of nodes in a cluster to handle more load, akin to adding more machines to a system.
Increasing the capacity of existing nodes, like upgrading the CPU or memory of current machines.
An open-source monitoring and alerting toolkit widely used for its simplicity and reliability.
An open-source analytics and interactive visualization web application that provides charts, graphs, and alerts for the web when connected to supported data sources.
A device that distributes network or application traffic across a number of servers, increasing the capacity and reliability of applications.
An API object that manages external access to the services in a Kubernetes cluster, typically HTTP.
A directory containing data, accessible to the containers in a pod, used to store application data and state.
